awd_titl_txt: CAREER:  A Comprehensive Framework for Disappearing Data
awd_abstract_narration: Numerous technical and environmental forces are increasing the importance of data privacy for businesses and individuals alike.  These forces include the migration of data to Web services, the permanent archiving of large volumes of data and communications by services and ISPs, and legal actions that are forcing individuals and organizations to reveal private (and even encrypted) data.  Traditional encryption is an insufficient solution under these conditions, thereby creating new challenges to preserving our digital privacy in an increasingly inter-connected and digital world.  This project tackles these challenges through the creation of a principled framework for protecting the privacy of past data -- such as copies of emails maintained by an email provider -- against accidental, malicious, and legal disclosure, even to entities who have access to the decryption keys.  This framework consists of both underlying technical mechanisms and prototype applications; these mechanisms and prototype applications are developed in concert to ensure the broadest applicability of the overall framework.  These prototype applications, by themselves, also directly address the privacy needs of broad classes of individuals, ranging from home users wishing to enhance the privacy of their email communications to voting machine manufacturers wishing to improve the privacy of electronic voting audit logs.

As people become more and more dependent on computers and as those computers begin to store information on the cloud, there is the potential for data to be collected and reside in places longer than the users might expect or hope. The first major goal of this project is to understand the real and perceived risks associated with data collection and preservation.  The second major goal of is to develop mechanisms to help users better control the lifetime of their data, either by preventing collection or by making the data disappear after a specified period of time. The third major goal of this project is focused on education to develop new methodologies for helping people learn the principles of computer security.

 

There have been multiple efforts throughout this project. One major effort focused on developing methods to protect data from retroactive disclosures. We developed a system, called Vanish, for encapsulating data such that the data will self-destruct and become permanently unreadable after a pre-specified timeout. We found that it is feasible to build a self-destructing data system under reasonable threat models, and that such systems can be aided by distributing shares of secret keys (using known secret sharing techniques) to parties with different trust relationships.

 

To complement the above work, we studied the use of a real (but not necessarily secure) self-destructing communications system: Snapchat. We learned that most of our participants (all 18 years old or older) do not use Snapchat to send sensitive content (although up to 25% may do so experimentally), that most respondents understand that messages can be recovered, and that security and privacy concerns are overshadowed by other influences on how and why respondents choose to use or not use Snapchat. Nevertheless, we find that a non-negligible fraction (though not a majority) of respondents have adapted or would adapt their behavior in response to understanding Snapchat’s (lack of) security properties, suggesting that there remains an opportunity for a more secure messaging application.

 

A second major effort, which resulted in the Keypad system, focused on developing methods for auditing access to data not physically in the possession of the auditor. For example, if a Keypad-protected hard drive is lost, the auditor can determine whether data on that hard drive is ever accessed. We found that it was possible to build such an auditing file system that is secure under reasonable threat models, but that there are tradeoffs between security and functionality.

 

A third major effort focused on understanding the quantity and impact of the information that websites collect about users as users browse the web. Building on this knowledge, we developed methods to help users better limit unwanted data collection by these websites. A concrete result of our research is ShareMeNot, a browser extension designed to help balance functionality with privacy for users of the web. ShareMeNot’s mechanisms have been incorporated into the EFF’s PrivacyBadger, a popular privacy-focused browser extension.
